articles.headline: Campaign to Drive Out Migrants Slams Beijing’s Best and Brightest
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of hopeful college graduates moved to the city seeking better jobs and better lives. Now the authorities are telling them to leave.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of hopeful college graduates moved to the city seeking better jobs and better lives. Now the authorities are telling them to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With coding skills, a foreign degree, fluent English and an apartment barely big enough for his espresso maker and two cats, Si Ruomu thought he was the kind of go-getting young tech worker that Beijing needs to thrive in the 21st century.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Sui-Lee Wee and Adam Wu

articles.headline: Europe’s Thirst for Cheap Labor Fuels a Boom in Disposable Workers
articles.snippet: Employment agencies across the region recruit thousands of migrants for Foxconn and other businesses, with conditions and pay that few in-country nationals would accept.
articles.abstract: Employment agencies across the region recruit thousands of migrants for Foxconn and other businesses, with conditions and pay that few in-country nationals would accept.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARDUBICE, Czech Republic — As dusk settled over the rambling Czech countryside, a group of haggard workers emerged from a dank three-story concrete dormitory and jammed into buses. The evening shift was about to begin at two nearby factories owned by Foxconn and Panasonic.

articles.headline: Alabama Senate Race, Unlikely Nail-Biter, Races to Finish Line
articles.snippet: Amid a blur of question marks and conflicting polls, Roy S. Moore, the Republican, and Doug Jones, the Democrat, made their final appeals to voters Monday.
articles.abstract: Amid a blur of question marks and conflicting polls, Roy S. Moore, the Republican, and Doug Jones, the Democrat, made their final appeals to voters Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Read the latest on the Alabama Senate race here with our live updates.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: The Alt-Right Created a Parallel Internet. It’s an Unholy Mess.
articles.snippet: Hard-right activists, censored and banned by Twitter and Facebook, tried to create their own digital services. But they appear to have hit obstacles.
articles.abstract: Hard-right activists, censored and banned by Twitter and Facebook, tried to create their own digital services. But they appear to have hit obstacles.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’ve lost sleep worrying about the growing power of the alt-right — that shadowy coalition that includes white nationalists, anti-feminists, far-right reactionaries and meme-sharing trolls — I may have found a cure for your anxiety.

articles.headline: Tawdry Tales Depict a Texas Congressman’s Frat House on the Hill
articles.snippet: Representative Blake Farenthold, the subject of an ethics investigation, set the tone for off-color jokes and inappropriate banter, legal documents and interviews with former aides suggest.
articles.abstract: Representative Blake Farenthold, the subject of an ethics investigation, set the tone for off-color jokes and inappropriate banter, legal documents and interviews with former aides suggest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Lauren Greene, a former communications director for Representative Blake Farenthold, sued him claiming sexual harassment, among her complaints was that he “disclosed that a female lobbyist had propositioned him for ‘a threesome.’”

articles.headline: More American Jobs? Broadcom Deal Might Mean the Opposite
articles.snippet: President Trump hailed Broadcom’s decision to bring its headquarters to the United States, but if its takeover bid for Qualcomm goes through, it may cost jobs.
articles.abstract: President Trump hailed Broadcom’s decision to bring its headquarters to the United States, but if its takeover bid for Qualcomm goes through, it may cost jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, President Trump stood in the Oval Office under a portrait of Andrew Jackson and announced that Broadcom, a semiconductor company based in Singapore, would be moving its headquarters back to the United States.

articles.headline: In Spending Spree, European Mall Operator Bets on Westfield
articles.snippet: Though malls are struggling, Unibail-Rodamco is set to acquire Westfield, the owner of shopping centers including the mall at One World Trade Center.
articles.abstract: Though malls are struggling, Unibail-Rodamco is set to acquire Westfield, the owner of shopping centers including the mall at One World Trade Center.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, the news has been nothing but bad for malls.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Sexual Harassment Cases Show the Ineffectiveness of Going to H.R.
articles.snippet: Human resources departments face a quandary: protect the employees who bring complaints or the companies that employ them.
articles.abstract: Human resources departments face a quandary: protect the employees who bring complaints or the companies that employ them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emery Lindsley was addressing her food and beverage staff at the Omni Corpus Christi Hotel in Texas in 2012 when a corporate executive suddenly placed his hand over her mouth to keep her from speaking.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Trump’s Combative Denials Again Draw Him Into the Sexual Harassment Debate
articles.snippet: In denying again the accusations against him and deriding Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, the president ensured that the issue would gain added energy and prominence.
articles.abstract: In denying again the accusations against him and deriding Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, the president ensured that the issue would gain added energy and prominence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump put himself once more at the center of the sexual harassment debate on Tuesday, repeating his contention that the women who have accused him of misconduct fabricated the allegations and describing Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, one of his leading critics, as a “lightweight” who “would do anything” for campaign contributions.
